reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***I picked this up at the rare video store on VHS since it seems it's not very well known or even on DVD.It's a surprisingly refreshing Supernatural horror film with elements of the 'Giallo' mixed in. Well directed, even creepy at times, it is very interesting.The plot deals with a professor who uncovers a sinister conspiracy. Filled with good camera-work, colorful and elaborate lighting and scenes in old city centers of Europe, it is enticing for the horror fan.If you liked this, I'd recommend: Zeder (1983)(aka "Zeder - Voices from Beyond" or "Revenge of the Dead"), The House of the Laughing Windows (1976), Suspiria (1977) and One Dark Night (1983).
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is an essential for the Italian horror film fanatic. It embodies everything people love about the genre- Amazing cinematography, creepy gothic settings, and balls to the wall gore. Most of the movie takes place in Budapest, a dark and gothic setting for the mystery of the spider cult. The plot reminded me of The Ninth Gate and The Serpent and the Rainbow. There's a professor who has arrived to study something or other, I don't remember the plot very well. He happens across a bunch of weirdos, there's monsters, and people getting torn apart. This is a very interesting film with some original ideas involving a group of people who worship a living god, this sort of spider-person. It's especially unsettling if you don't like spiders. The ending is a real shocker, and quite disgusting. I am really glad this is out on DVD now, because this was always a super obscure film and I never knew anyone else who had seen it besides me. The version I saw was a Japanese bootleg ripped from a grainy VHS tape. I can't wait to see the DVD on a big screen HD TV, it's going to be creepy.
summary: Amazing Film, a lesser known classic Italian horror film

reviewText: I am sorry, but it seems that every Italian film I own is dubbed poorly. It gets on my nerves. This movie is no exception. The transfer looks like it's from an early 80's VHS and the color isn't quite right. The acting is wooden, but the secretary and the sex scenes with her are hot. The plot is predictable, yet the movie does have some scares and it does show respect for the great HPL. So, I gave it four stars for sex and glory.

reviewText: The Spider Labyrinth (Gianfranco Giagni, 1988)When I started watching Il Nido del Ragno, which can be seen in English-speaking countries as either Spider Labyrinth or The Spider's Nest, I wasn't exactly sure what to expect. I'm a giallo fan, have been for decades, but I've seen enough bad low-budget giallo to know that the genre itself is in no way a guarantee of quality. And as the first half-hour or so of this flick unrolled, I figured I was in for another crappy movie. But then something happened. I can't quite put my finger on what it was, but somewhere along the line I became enthralled with this movie in a way I haven't with any Italian film since I first discovered Dellamorte Dell'Amore over a decade ago. I can't give it a rave review because the first part of the film still feels so incredibly bad, but once it gets going, it's a barnburner of the highest (and cheesiest) order, and it's wonderful.There's a bunch of setup about ancient texts and translation and that sort of thing, but it's all a pretext to get our hero, Alan Whitmore (Roland Wybenga, in the second of the just three films he would make in the twelve-month period that comprised his career), to Budapest, where he's supposed to locate a reclusive academic named Roth. Roth is nowhere to be found, but that gets pushed to the back of Alan's mind as soon as he meets Genevieve (Cicciabomba's Paola Rinaldi in her final film role to date), the professor's seductive secretary. Soon after, Roth is found dead, and Alan starts to wonder if the same people who killed Roth will be after him next...The cheese factor here escalates with the amount of special effects, which makes the final fifteen minutes some of the cheesiest you will ever see. This is what prevents Giagni (Nobody's Heart) from rising to the level of a Soavi. But let's remember that Argento, that undisputed master of seventies Italian horror flicks, was also well-known for coming up with painfully cheesy endings (think here of Inferno, Suspiria, and Tenebre, three of his most popular movies). So I feel like I have to go lighter on Giagni than I normally would, given my love of mid-era Argento. And really, even while you recognize how awful the special effects are, you kind of have to admit it's a really kick-ass ending. It blows the suspension of disbelief straight into the middle of next week, but it's so stupidly fun you don't actually care. And it wouldn't be if Giagni hadn't built the tension well enough to make you care what's going on.A flawed film to be sure, but a minor gem nonetheless. If you're a fan of cheesy European horror from the seventies and eighties, this one's a must-see. ***
summary: Inconsistent, but when it's on, it's on.

reviewText: After reading the reviews on this particular one for sale I had to back off and hold onto my Japanese boot with subtitles.At least it is in widescreen and the picture is decent for what it is.I would hope that Blue Underground or someone else would put this out on a nice legit dvd release.Maybe its hard to get a hold of the master print.Who knows.Lets keep our fingers crossed.

reviewText: This was a fun horror movie. It reminded me a bit of Rosemary's Baby in that it involves a secret cult where the lead characters seeming paranoia about those around him turns out to be horribly true fears. A professor in dead languages goes to Budapest to talk to a colleage. But things get weird when hte colleage is mysteriously killed. It all surrounds a cult of spider monster worshipers. The professor soon gets tangles in a web, pun intended of the spider cult. A fun horror film, nicely done.
summary: Spider Cult is going to get you!
